awd_titl_txt: TECt: Preparing Northeast Florida's Secondary Teachers to Foster Computational Thinking in Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of North Florida (UNF) will implement Teachers Enhancing Computational Thinking (TECt): Preparing Northeast Florida's Secondary Teachers to Foster Computational Thinking in Computer Science -- to build on current collaborative initiatives to prepare 30 teachers to teach computer science (CS) courses through professional development (PD) and coursework leading to state certification in CS. TECt will engage multiple partners from UNF, Duval County Public Schools, and the Northeast Florida STEM2 Hub, along with CS teachers and experts in education, CS and business in addressing the gap in the availability and access to CS courses. 

High school students in Duval County in northeast Florida typically graduate without any CS instruction. Although a state certification exists for CS K-12 instructors, no local colleges or universities offer teacher certification programs. As a result, few teachers can become fully prepared CS educators, and few students are exposed to meaningful computer science instruction. TECt will change that, using a science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) Ecosystems framework within a Research-Practitioner Partnership (RPP) to prepare and support these teachers in teaching rigorous CS courses. The RPP will define the problems of practice, address equity throughout the partnership, and implement research to determine the effectiveness of the TECt structure in preparing high school CS teachers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The Teaching Educators Computational thinking (TECt) program at the University of North Florida was designed to achieve three primary goals:

1. Build strong foundations for STEM/CS literacy across all courses;

2. Increase diversity, equity, and inclusion in STEM/CS; and

3. Prepare the STEM/CS workforce for the future.

The University of North Florida College of Education and Human Services (COEHS) and Duval County Public Schools (DCPS) created important connections between university faculty and practitioners. This partnership delivered of professional development coordinated of PD with DCPS and UNF and utilized multiple modalities. The first included a four-course certificate that incorporated key competencies necessary for effective computer science (CS) and computational thinking (CT) teaching.

Computer Science Coursework, Delivery Schedule, and Delivery Modes, Updated Course

Delivery Model

Timeline

IDC 2000 Beauty and Joy of Computing

Face-to-Face & Asynchronous

Co 1-Spring 2020; Co 2-Fall 2020

ESE 2210 Intro to CS for Teachers

Online Synchronous and Asynchronous meetings

Co 1-Fall 2020, Co 2-Spring 2021

COP 2251 Intro to Object Oriented Programming

Online Synchronous

Fall 2021 C1 & 2 combined

ESE 2211 Teaching CS in High Schools

Online Synchronous and Asynchronous meetings

Spring 2021 C1 & 2 combined

 

Incorporated into this course sequence, TECt participants were expected to participate in Professional Learning Communities (PLCs) focused on implementation challenges, data studies, and coaching strategies. The project concluded with a Research Practitioner Partnership Summit. At the TECt Summit, participants shared CS/CT curricular work that impacted their instruction.

Online, self-paced modules were drafted in Summer 2022 by TECt participants. created professional development modules centered on preparing future computer science teachers for the competencies required for the Florida K-12 computer science certification exam.

 

Outcomes

The delivery of high-quality Professional Development and coordination of delivery with DCPS has received high praise from program participants. The content of the coursework was highly valued as well as the contributions of instructors who provided highly valued examples of pedagogy. Implementation fidelity related to leadership and project management activities has generally been viewed positively by the external evaluation team. Engaging partners, both in education and in the community at-large, has generally proceeded as effectively as possible, given the constraints placed on the Project by the COVID health crisis. Implementation fidelity related to recruitment has not been met as enrollment numbers have fallen short of those planned in the Project.

A summative evaluation was conducted to address the effectiveness and impact of TECt and serve as the basis for recommending subsequent work toward the goals of the program. A summary of the quantitative analysis in the evaluation has concluded that, while all assessments showed slight to moderate improvements over the course of TECt. Qualitative analysis of TECt participants through focus group interviews revealed a high regard for the coursework and professors delivering that coursework.

Two school-based programs have been stimulated and supported through the direct efforts of participants in the TECt project and there is an expectation that additional schools will increase their CS program offerings.

Advanced STEM/CS course offerings, including an increase in student enrollment and completions was expected to be a longer-term outcome as the work of the teachers prepared through TECt gradually impact their colleagues and the increase in course offerings available to students. Nevertheless, some increase has been seen in completions and enrollments of students in advanced STEM and CS courses.

 


Last Modified: 01/25/2023
Modified by: Brian Zoellner
